title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message:
About halfway through startup a horizontal narrow band of colours appears about an eighth of the way from the top of the screen and then it reboots. A workshop I use for iPhone board repairs helped diagnose it over the phone and after disabling AMD GPU and seeing it work on the slow Intel GPU, said this would need a GPU replacement so I paid them to do it as I don't have a BGA machine. However, it has made no difference whatsoever.

The lower RAM slot doesn't work. I have tried known good RAM chips in the upper slot as well as disconnecting everything but the bare minimum.

Any suggestions on how to proceed would be greatly appreciated.

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: Damn. There's definitely no chance it could be anything else at all? I've seen many different symptoms of bad GPU and to see exactly the same symptom after a GPU replacement does seem like quite a coincidence don't you think?

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: No this is a bad GPU like always. If you have no way to replace these then 95% of 2914/2915 boards are unfixable for you as it is always the GPU.

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: Can you recommend any good sources of these chips? The last one came from AliExpress.

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: All chips on Ali are fake garbage. I think SEE on Ebay has some real ones right now, ask them.

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message:
The symptoms I'm having seem to resemble the ones in this post: [URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/29878-820-2915-gpu-replacement"]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards...pu-replacement[/URL]

The glue was not removed from the memory chips on the other side of the board when the GPU was removed.

What is needed for reflowing the memory chips temperature-wise? Will I need a profile with a BGA machine or can I just blast the hot air station onto it with some flux?

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: If you have no BGA machine you have no business even touching this board. The GPU needs to be replaced to start with.

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: The point is, I paid somebody to replace the GPU and when the board came back it was doing exactly the same as it was when I sent it to them. So my question is: Is there something more than the GPU that could be causing the problem, i.e., the GPU RAM? But regardless of everything, is it not fair that I can ask the question: If I want to reflow the RAM, is there a specific temperature profile I need to adhere to or can I just pre-heat the board and reflow with flux as I would do any other chip?

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: What date code is the GPU that was put on there?

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message:
I don't know what the date code is. This is what's written on it:

1134
PBX093.00
216-0810084

title: 820-2914-B band of colours during startup then reboot
message: 1134 is a chip from 2011 week 34, so I bet they just reflowed or reballed the old one that was on there. Get your money back and forget about this project.
